titleStmt.title: Converting Word documents to TEI XML in oXygen

body.head: Can you convert Word documents to TEI XML in oXygen?
body.p: A Word docx file is actually a compressed archive containing several other files, including XML files which can be manipulated and converted in the same way as any other XML file. oXygen knows this, and comes with predefined XSLT stylesheets for converting from docx to TEI P5. The conversion can also take into account any Word styles found, which makes it possible to customize the way your Word file,is converted, in order to produce more intelligent markup than would otherwise be possible.
In this little tutorial we'll step through the process, using as example a test file produced by the DifDepo project. If you want to play along, you can download the test file from here

list.item: In oXygen, use the usual Open dialog to select the docx file
A window opens to the left of the main screen headed "Navigateur d'Archives". It shows the file structure of the docx archive.
Click the blue key next to the folder called word to see the contents of this folder
Select the file called document.xml and double click to open it (may take a few moments if the file is large)
As you see, this is an XML document, with lots of XML tags, using many different namespaces, most of them defined by Microsoft. Let's convert it!

With the document.xml file open in your main editing window, select Transformation -> Configurer les Scenarios de transformation from the Document menu. Or type CTRL-MAJ-C. Or click the little spanner icon (this one : )
oXygen shows you the transformation options available for this kind of document. This should include one called DOCX TEI P5, which is the default TEI conversion.

To see what it does, check the little box next to it, and press the Appliquer associe(s) button at the bottom. A new window opens at the bottom of the screen in which oXygen displays messages relating to the conversion process ; you may safely ignore these.

In the main editing window, you should now see a TEI-conformant document. (Choose Source > Indenter le document from the Document menu, or type CTRL-MAJ-P or click the Indent button (this one: ) if it is displayed as a single line on the screen) Scroll down to see how the Word styles have been converted.

Note that many of the paragraphs have a rend attribute. The values of this attribute correspond with the Word style used in the original docx file. You can use these values to make a more intelligent conversion.
Close the tab labelled Test_tous-styles-TEI-P5.xml to return to the window containing document.xml, your source Word document.

Click on the spanner again to reopen the Configurer Scenarios de Transformation dialog and this time click the Edit button at the bottom. This will enable you to reconfigure the bdefault conversion process.
You can't modify a built in configuration scenario, so oXyGen offers to make a copy for you to play with. . Press Oui.
The editer le scenario ANT is displayed to enable you to configure your new version of the transformation scenario.
Let's begin by changing its name to something sensible: change "DOCX TEI P5 copier" to "DOCX TEI P5 Oulipo" for example. Then press the Parametres tab to see what else can be modified.

This dialog allows us to change the default input and output paths for this transformation and also to specify a profile. The TEI Stylesheet package included with oXygen supplies a small number of predefined sets of customized stylesheets called profiles. You can use or modify an existing profile to get the effects you want in your own project (not covered here). In this exercise, we will use the Oulipo profile.
Select the word Profile and press the Edition button.
Add the word oulipo in the box labelled Valeur and press Accepter to return to the Editer le scenario Ant dialog. Press Accepter again.
Your new transformation scenario should now be available in the Configurer Transformation Scenario dialog. Check the little box next to it, and uncheck the box next to the default Scenario.

This OULIPO profile includes rules to handle the Word styles which were simply passed through as values for the rend attribute in the default transformation scenario. (These rules are written in XSLT; we don't tell you here how to write them). Run the transformation again, by pressing Appliquer associes. You should see something rather different this time...
